sn11.12:4.2: There the Buddha said to the mendicants:
sn11.12:4.3: “Mendicants, in a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he was a brahmanical student named Magha. That’s why he’s called Maghavā.
sn11.12:5.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave gifts in stronghold after stronghold. That’s why he’s called Purindada, the stronghold-giver.
sn11.12:6.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave gifts carefully. That’s why he’s called Sakka, the careful.
sn11.12:7.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he gave the gift of a guest house. That’s why he’s called Vāsava, the houser.
sn11.12:8.1: Sakka thinks of a thousand things in a moment. That’s why he’s called Sahassakkha, Thousand-Eye.
sn11.12:9.1: Sakka’s wife is the demon maiden named Sujā. That’s why he’s called Sujampati, Sujā’s husband.
sn11.12:10.1: Sakka rules as sovereign lord over the gods of the Thirty-Three. That’s why he’s called Lord of Gods.
sn11.12:11.1: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.
sn11.12:11.3: As long as I live, may I support my parents. As long as I live, may I honor the elders in the family. As long as I live, may I speak gently. As long as I live, may I not speak divisively. As long as I live, may I live at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share. As long as I live, may I speak the truth. As long as I live, may I be free of anger,
sn11.12:11.4: or should anger arise, may I quickly get rid of it.
sn11.12:11.5: In a former life, when Sakka was a human being, he undertook seven vows. And it was because of undertaking these that he achieved the status of Sakka.”
sn11.12:12.2: and honors the elders in the family,
sn11.12:12.3: whose speech is gentle and courteous,
sn11.12:13.1: who’s committed to getting rid of stinginess,
sn11.12:13.2: is truthful, and has mastered anger:
sn11.12:13.4: call them truly a good person.”
